In ones and twos Kosovo Albanians approach the mortuary at Pristina's main hospital every day and look at the clothes hanging out to dry. Usually they go away frustrated but sometimes they recognise a T-shirt or a pair of trousers and break down in tears. It is proof at last that a husband, father, or son is dead.

For Detective Superintendent Steve Watts, the head of the British forensic team which has been exhuming bodies on behalf of the war crimes tribunal in the Hague, the scenes have been heart-rending. "By now most bodies are skeletal and there are very sparse dental records in Kosovo. So items of clothing are often the only chance to identify people'" he said.

The exhumers photograph the remains, count the bodies and check for signs of the cause of death. When it comes to identifying people, usually they can do little more than determine the age and sex - except for bits of clothing, which are examined and then washed.

Remarkable

Clothing displays have been organised elsewhere in Kosovo. At the most recent, at the bread factory in Fushe Kosove, grieving families recognised 15% of the articles. "I thought this was a remarkable proportion," said Det Supt Watts.

In the first year of the tribunal's operations in Kosovo, when bodies were fresher, the rate was higher. Roughly two-thirds of the 2,108 bodies exhumed in 1999 were identified.

This year the British team, the largest in the territory, has been concentrating on two sites. It has dug up 180 bodies at a cemetery in Dragodan, a suburb of Pristina. They were found in unmarked pits, and often one hole had two or three bodies in it. "Was it intended to hide the bodies?", Det Supt Watts asked.

At Makoc, near Pristina, the team reopened graves dug by Albanian villagers shortly after the war to give a dignified burial to 61 people who had last been seen when Serb forces separated them from a refugee column. Here the tribunal team's aim was to determine the cause of death. Many had gunshot wounds in the skull, apparently fired at close range.

This year's digging by the British team has produced no evidence of bodies having been burnt. This would be a strong clue to deliberate tampering.

The long battle for control of Welsh utility group Hyder ended last night when Japanese investment bank Nomura International decided not to appeal against the takeover panel decision giving victory to the rival bidder, Western Power Distribution.

Nomura's managing director, Guy Hands, said the group was disappointed by the outcome but added: "We have decided not to prolong the period of uncertainty for Hyder's stakeholders, particularly the employees, who have been through a great deal over the last few months."

A spokesman for WPD said: "We are pleased certainty has been provided for Hyder shareholders."

The four-month battle came to a chaotic climax at the end of last week after the takeover panel executive imposed a sealed bid procedure in the final stages of the offer period. WPD put in a sealed bid of 365p a share, and though announcement of the offer was made after the deadline, the executive allowed it to stand.

Nomura, which had opposed the imposition of the sealed bid procedure, appealed against the ruling to the full panel earlier this week but was again overruled. It could have continued to seek to overturn the ruling by taking its case to the panel's appeals committee and, ultimately, could have sought a judicial review of the procedings, but last night decided to withdraw.

Although Nomura has decided not to carry on the bid battle, a spokesman said last night that it was too early to say what it would do with the 16.2% stake it had built up in Hyder. The most likely outcome is that it will sell the stake, which would bring it a profit of more than £25m.

The bid terms are more than double the price to which Hyder shares had fallen earlier this year as the group struggled with debts of £1.8bn.

"We continue to believe there is substantial value in Hyder and at least one group of stakeholders, the shareholders, should be pleased that the share price has nearly doubled since our involvement first become public, " said Mr Hands.

Hyder's operations include Welsh Water, the regulated water and waste water business, and South Wales Electricity. WPD plans to add Hyder's electricity distribution business to its own power network in south-west England and will contract out some of Hyder's water services to United Utilities.

Weeks of double-dealing caught up with "nasty" Nick Bateman last night when his scheming ways led to eviction from the voyeuristic television game show Big Brother.

Nick's fellow contestants dragged themselves out of self-absorption for long enough to figure out the truth that to the nation had appeared obvious. After discovering his attempts to manipulate nominations that decide who is thrown out of the show, they confronted him with his crimes. Tension became so high that it almost came to blows, and nervous producers pulled the plug on the show's live webcast.

The link was restored later, in time for fans to watch emotional scenes that rivalled the best of British television for dramatic tension. Nick hit back with claims that his public school and City background had conditioned his competitive instincts.

As it became clear that the former Lloyd's broker was prepared to brazen it out, Channel 4 stepped in to give him the boot for "persistent infringement" of the Big Brother rules.

The winner of Big Brother's £70,000 prize is the last person left in the house after contestants and members of the public have voted the rest out. Nick had been writing notes and showing them to fellow contestants in an attempt to influence their voting intentions. "The rules of Big Brother expressly forbid contestants from talking about nominations and tactical voting," Channel 4 said. His position was untenable.

Because Nick leaves the show outside of the weekly eviction process, his place will be taken by a replacement drawn from a list of back-up candidates. The new contestant's identity has not yet been announced.

The website took 6m hits yesterday, making Big Brother by far the most popular event to have been broadcast on the internet in Britain.

Despite his lack of popularity with viewers, Nick's tactics had proved a success with his housemates. Each week the participants must nominate two of their number for eviction - the public has the final say in a telephone vote - but not once did they pick Nick.

Dr Linda Papadopoulos, the show's counselling psychologist, told the Big Brother website yesterday: "He realised who everyone wanted to be and he allowed them to be just that person when he was with them. He played them."

Such was the scale of his deviousness that rumours spread that he was a Channel 4 mole. The press reported that he had smuggled in a mobile phone, but a search found nothing.

Last night Nick was holed up in a hotel in central London with his family, a psychologist, and minders from the programme, as the events of yesterday were screened in an extended programme on Channel 4. His eviction - and that of Craig or Nichola, depending on the outcome of this week's vote - will be shown on tonight's broadcasts.

The world's long romance with speed may finally be ending. Even if Concorde flies again, its antique nature was revealed as soon as the Paris accident made people scratch their heads and ask quite why these odd aircraft were still flying. Much of the technology that surrounds us has, when we look at it afresh, this Jules Verne quality - solving problems that once seemed important in ways that are ingenious but not necessarily efficient or safe.

The reorientation of science toward the biological and computer frontiers is now an old story, but the 19th-century fascination with motive power has retained a powerful hold on our imaginations and our economies. One of the curious things about the last century is that almost every technological development that actually took place had been imagined and considered in fiction and non-fiction in the years before the first world war.

When these developments actually arrived they were thus already freighted with meaning, and were never simply neutral means to ends. Advances in motive power were for a long while the main way in which progress and national competition in technology were measured. First at sea, then on the railways, then on the roads, in the air and finally in space, more and more rapid movement was seen as an unalloyed good and also, in some hazy way, as a key to a fuller understanding of the world. All kinds of speed were interconnected, forming a transmission belt to a future which people believed would be radically changed.

The early 20th century approach to the revolution in transportation had already parted company from purely practical considerations to imagine what now seem rather tenuous intellectual, political and emotional advantages. HG Wells and Rudyard Kipling, for instance, both imagined world states based on air dictatorships. Space travel, it was implied by its proponents, might in the end allow the whole universe to be completely understood. So intoxicating was this ultimate way in which the growing speed and reach of man-made vehicles could be used that when an unknown rocket buff called Hermann Oberth published his By Rocket to Interplanetary Space in the 1920s, it represented such an escape from the difficulties of the present to the anxious citizens of Weimar Germany that it became a bestseller overnight. Later Fritz Lang transmuted Oberth's propositions into a hit film, The Girl in the Moon.

The destination was important, but sheer velocity was almost always part of the formula. For individual sportsmen, pilots and drivers, speed had the status of a privileged substance to which, in those early days, only a minority had full access. Passengers and spectators participated but in a lesser way. Mechanised speed made men, and a few women, into heroes, and it remains a commodity to which males, in particular, are attracted. The front of the Boys Own annual of half a century ago would typically feature a speeding train in the middle ground, a fast aeroplane above, and a racing car in the foreground. Such icons are still with us.

Disentangling the genuine advantages of speed from its cult aspects has always been a problem, and this was certainly the case in the era in which Concorde was conceived. Land, air and sea speed records had mattered since the 20s in a way inconceivable today and all the advanced nations strove to run faster, swim faster, drive faster, fly faster, and, later, to shoot missiles higher and further than other countries.

This manic race was run on three tracks - of celebrity sport, of competition between civil industries and of military development. All three were littered with casualties, whether it was spectators at Le Mans, Donald Campbell on Coniston Water, or numerous test pilots and astronauts through the years.

Britain was slowing down on all three courses when Concorde came along. Indeed the Concorde project survived in part because Britain had just had to discard three advanced military aircraft programmes and wanted to keep at least one prestige effort going. The other reason, as Harold Wilson explained in his memoirs, was that the agreement with the French was embodied in an international treaty, and they refused even to consider abandoning or postponing the work.

If Britain tried to pull out, Wilson says, we would probably have had to pay half the costs of what would then be developed as a wholly French aeroplane. "Faced with this situation," he noted, "we had little choice but to go on." His lack of enthusiasm suggests that long before Concorde actually flew, some of those responsible for it knew that it was not going to be a practical aircraft, and also that the technical spin-off would be less than advertised. The reason was that speed was such a dominant consideration that everything else had to take second place. The result was an aircraft that was both ahead of its time and behind the times, since the era of small-scale luxury air travel was over.

The preoccupation with speed has always gone hand in hand with a preoccupation with safety, the two standards between them providing a way in which advanced states calibrate the state of civilisation. Increasing speeds have indicated technical progress, while accidents indicate loss of control. The first world lives in constant fear of regression, of losing the scientific and organisational edge that enables it to be both fast and safe. That is one reason why air and sea accidents can attain such mythic status. Of the Titanic, one British newspaper observed: "The ship is a kind of metaphor for the whole civilisation," a thought often echoed since then. The disparate treatment of first and third world accidents in the western press is probably due more to the feeling that accidents are indicators of technical health, than to any devaluation of African or Asian lives.

Speed still has its kingdom, but it is shrinking. Its limits have long ago been reached on the roads, and its value in the air, even for manned military aircraft, is diminished - agility and protection are as or more important. It is still marginally attractive to make trains go faster. Australia is contemplating a TGV link between Sydney and Canberra, for instance. But the obsession with speed is fading: shaving the hours, minutes, and seconds off physical movement just does not matter now in the way that it once did. The pursuit of physical speed has been replaced by the pursuit of near instantaneity on the net, an aim which we may in time come to regard just as sceptically.

It is hard to imagine now the mood in which David Lean's The Sound Barrier was made in 1952, with its heroic test pilot dying in the cause of speed. The sound barrier then was an obstacle beyond which seemed to lie the answer to a mystery. But there was no real mystery. Man can go faster, but that does not mean it is necessarily worth doing so.

More than £800m has been wasted on a "fraud free" benefit swipe card for 17m claimants which will never be used, parliament's financial watchdog reveals today.

The card, flourished at the 1995 Conservative party conference by Peter Lilley, then social security secretary, was cancelled by his Labour successor, Alastair Darling, last May after ministers were told they were throwing away £15m a month on a system that could never work.

The national audit office said taxpayers have lost £127m; ICL, the computer company that designed the product, £180m; and the Post Office is facing a £571m loss, to cover the debacle.

The card was ordered by the benefits agency and the Post Office as a fraud-proof way of paying out more than 24 benefits to 17m claimants at 20,000 post offices in the United Kingdom. The card, which would have cost £1bn in total, promised to handle 760m payments to claimants a year and save the ministry £100m a year by making benefit fraud impossible.

The auditors reveal that even when the card was commissioned in 1996 civil servants knew it was a high risk project. Papers from the time reveal ICL's card system had "weak authentication procedures and the weakest security proposals", and the company's subsidiary, Pathway, had a "manifest lack of under standing of the management of fraud risk".

Despite misgivings, Whitehall ordered the system before 289 operational problems had been solved because it fitted in with the Tory government's support of private finance initiatives, in which the private sector takes some of the risk.

The card was used to pay child benefit in 10 post offices in Gloucestershire under the Tories. Later Labour extended it to pay child benefit in 205 post offices in the south-west and north-east of England in November 1997.

After 18 months of further negotiations Labour scrapped the project in May last year, deciding to go ahead with the automation of post offices without the new card. Instead benefit payments would be paid direct to bank and post office accounts. The scale of the scandal led Tony Blair to order the Cabinet Office to review the handling of future large scale hi-tech projects by Whitehall.

Sir John Bourn, the comptroller and auditor general, is livid about Whitehall's handling of the project. In today's report he puts the blame on the "organisational myopia" in Whitehall which allowed "fundamental flaws in the design of the management of the scheme".

He also blames rows between the Post Office and the Department of Social Security, which had different priorities in using the card. Social security wanted to curb fraud; the Post Office wanted to expand its business under automation.

"Although in theory projects can be run by two or more organisations, in practice this is a recipe for dispute and delay, which is what happened in this case," Sir John said.

He is critical of "the insufficient work that went into specifying the project and for demonstrations by bidders".

"The result of skimping at the start was vast delay and as it turned out, wasted money."

Sir John, who says that in hi-tech projects "mistakes like this are being made time and time again", calls for sweeping changes, including the appointment of one person in Whitehall, a "risk scrutineer", to take responsibility for each major project.

David Davis, chairman of the House of Commons' public accounts committee, said he hoped the NAO's report would mark a watershed in the way Whitehall managed information technology projects.

"Today's report by the NAO is the latest, and probably worst, example in a long line of public sector IT debacles," said Mr Davis, Conservative MP for Haltemprice and Howden.

Mr Darling welcomed the report: "We cancelled the benefits payment card because it was three years late, costs were escalating and in any event the card would have been obsolete in five years time. It would have been utterly irresponsible to continue with the project.

"The cost of making payments by the card would have been 65p per payment. The cost of making payments by automatic credit transfer is less than 1p per payment. The move to automatic credit transfer from 2003 will virtually eliminate £100m of fraud in benefit payments annually."

David Rendel, Liberal Democrat member of the public accounts committe, said: "The project has been a disaster from start to finish. It has cost the Post Office millions and threatened the future of the post office network ... and the public sector has ended up footing most of the bill."

Computer errors

The passport agency Two years ago thousands of people had to queue outside the agency's London headquarters after a new computer system, developed with the German firm Siemens, to issue passports failed to deliver. The system is now on course but the taxpayer lost £12.5m.

Civil aviation authority Millions of holiday air passengers are facing delays because a £623m air traffic control centre at Swanwick, Hampshire has not opened. The computerised system does not work and will need more modification before it enters service.

Inland revenue Computerisation of the Inland Revenue undertaken by EDS. Cost of the contract is now £2.4bn - £1bn higher than first planned.

Contributions agency Some 172,000 Serps pensioners lost between 1p and £100 a week last year when a computer system developed by Andersen Consulting for 65m national insurance accounts could not handle all the data.

Immigration directorate Thousands of immigration and asylum seekers had to endure hardship and anxiety after a computer system, also designed by Siemens, was not suitable to handle the applications. The result was a backlog of 219,000 cases.

Not everything fails. The £28m Home Office tagging scheme for prisoners has been praised. About 21,000 people have been tagged and in 94% of cases it has worked.

Safety risks with "potentially serious consequences" have been uncovered in John Prescott's plans to partly privatise the London Underground, less than six months before contracts are due to be signed, a private letter from the government's chief rail inspector has revealed.

In a memorandum to the company's management last week, which has been passed to the Guardian, the principal rail safety inspector, Stanley Hart, warned of a "growing concern" about safety in the partly sold-off tube system that the deputy prime minister wants to bring in next spring.

Describing himself as frustrated, Mr Hart accused London Underground of overseeing a "breakdown in local management control" in the structures that had been set up for the plans, with "either no proof that the systems work or proof that they are not working".

The disclosure comes at a highly sensitive time for the government, in the run-up to the Labour party conference next month.

Its plans to break up the tube and bring in private companies to run the infrastructure are likely to come under strong attack from trade unionists and party activists.

The catalogue of disasters since the privatisation of British Rail and the admission by the rail inspectorate at the Paddington crash inquiry this year that it had failed to keep a grip on the fragmented private industry have made the issue of safety in the plans for London Underground more sensitive.

Mr Prescott's Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions and the health and safety executive - of which the rail inspectorate is part - yesterday refused to comment on the leaked letter.

But the London mayor, Ken Livingstone, who made opposition to the partial tube sell-off a central plank of his election campaign, seized on the letter as evidence of the dangers of pressing ahead, although he has no legal powers to stop the deals.

"This letter will confirm Londoners' worst fears about the government's public-private partnership scheme and highlights the risk of a Paddington-style crash underground," he said last night.

"The partial sell-off is a threat to the lives of Londoners. The government should heed these warnings and withdraw their dangerous and ill-conceived plans."

The government intends to pass on responsibility for the tube to Mr Livingstone only after it has handed over the infrastructure - accounting for about half the business - to private sector companies on the basis of 30-year contracts.

The network is being split into three parts, and bids are already in for two of them. If the contracts go ahead as planned early next year the structure could be locked in place for a generation.

In his letter, Mr Hart said his inspectorate had "consistently expressed a growing concern that it does not have full confidence" in London Underground's systems being "shadowed" in preparation for break-up and part-privatisation.

It was vital that there was an effective system of ensuring compliance with safety rules, he said. "There is evidence that these criteria are not being met consistently."

A "further disquieting aspect" was the lack of central responsibility in the planned system, when central co-ordination was "essential", he added.

Telecoms company Thus yesterday insisted that it was not involved in takeover talks even as it fired off notices forcing holders of its shares to come clean about their identity.

Royal Navy and civilian divers are this morning slowly heading up the Norwegian coast with a lingering hope of rescuing some of the 118 Russian sailors trapped on the bed of the Barents Sea.

It may be too late by the time they arrive, tomorrow afternoon, to carry out what would be an astonishing rescue mission. But it seems to be the last hope. "The Russians recognise we represent the best opportunity for a timely rescue," a Royal Navy submariner said yesterday.

Ministry of Defence officials who have been in touch with the Russian navy since the beginning of the week said yesterday this was not the time for recrimination. As far as the Royal Navy is concerned, this is a humanitarian mission.

Whatever reticence the Russians had has evaporated. "All our questions have been answered," said an MoD official involved in the rescue plans.

Yesterday, the white LR5 rescue vehicle, described by Mike Finney, former commander of a nuclear submarine, as an "underwater helicopter," was lifted on to the Normand Pioneer, chartered by the navy, at the Norwegian port of Trondheim.

Its advantage is that it can operate independently and navigate with pinpoint accuracy. But its top speed is 3 knots. "It will not be easy, ocean currents are a law unto themselves," a navy submariner said.

The plan is for three Russians, including a doctor, to join the LR5's crew in the first attempt to open the escape hatch on the Kursk's stern. The LR5 will also carry oxygen, food, and electric power.

"You cannot tell whether it is too late. No one can tell if they're out of oxygen," Commander David Stanesby said in Trondheim.

A naval spokesman in London added: "If there's anyone inside who can open the hatch we will be very, very excited by that."

If no one does, the LR5 crew will open the hatch, a manoeuvre they have achieved on exercises. If they succeed, 16 Russian sailors will enter the rescue vehicle after passing through an attached decompression chamber. They will be taken to the surface, unloaded, and the LR5 will return to the Kursk, 108 metres down. Each operation will take three to four hours.

In remarkable testimony to the Russian navy's spirit of cooperation, born out of desperation, Commodore David Russell, deputy flag officer submarines, will help to oversee the rescue operation on board the Russian flagship, Peter the Great. He will be accompanied by three other Royal Navy officers, including a Russian speaker.

The Ministry of Defence insisted that chartering the Normand Pioneer was the quickest way to prepare for the rescue mission.

The runway at Murmansk, Russia's northern naval base closest to the Kursk, was not long enough to take the Antonov aircraft which flew the LR5 to Trondheim on Wednesday, according to an MoD official.

Russia's deputy naval chief of staff, Alexander Pobozhy, sidestepped questions about why the LR5 was flown to Norway instead of a Russian airfield. "It was the most optimum option for us," he said after a meeting at Nato headquarters in Brussels. "It was the most acceptable option for us."

Norway is sending 12-15 deep-sea divers, with experience from offshore oil and gas exploration, to assist the British mission.

Admiral Pobozhy said after the Brussels meeting that there could still be many days before oxygen ran out. "From our experience with the Soviet submarine forces, it can be as long as two to three weeks."

The atmosphere at the meeting was described as "very open and expert".

"There was a real spirit of cooperation," said a Nato source.

This week, before the horrified gaze of the world, the Kursk has become part of the swelling armada of dead Russian nuclear submarines, most of which are to be found in the ports of the Kola peninsula of north-west Russia.

If the tragedy focuses attention on Russia's ballooning nuclear waste problem, then some good may yet come of it. What has been lacking has been political will in Russian and abroad. The loss of the Kursk could change that. There is still time - just.

From a radiation point of view, the Kola peninsula is one of the cleanest places in Europe. A bit of strontium 90 from the atmospheric atom bomb test of the 1950s, to be sure - you get that everywhere. On land, there is background radon (as on Dartmoor). In the Barents, Kara and White seas, there is caesium 137, but half of that comes from jolly old Windscale/Sellafield.

But Kola also boasts the greatest latent potential for catastrophic release of radioactivity on the planet. An audit of 1993, ordered by President Boris Yeltsin, opened the issue for scrutiny. Kola is home to huge numbers of operating and defunct reactors.

Between 1954 and 1996, the Soviet Union built 287 nuclear submarines, containing more than 500 reactors. Of these, a minimum of 183 - and perhaps as many as 245 - are now out of service, and at least 120 of those still have fuelled reactors. The Northern Fleet has 142 subs and three battlecruisers (300-plus reactors) in or out of service. Then there are 10 icebreakers and a container ship. In the tally are 16 dumped reactors, including six with unrecovered fuel from nuclear accidents, such as the one that overtook the icebreaker Lenin. To that must now be added the two fuelled reactors of the Kursk.

So Kola has an abundance of spent nuclear fuel from ships needing containment. Then there is the Kola power station. Two of its reactors are judged by the International Atomic Energy Authority to have a 25% likelihood of critical failure in the next 20 years. There is no containment. This, however, is the power station that powers the pumps that cool the shut-down submarine reactors that await decommissioning and disposal. When the electricity company cut the Russian navy off for non-payment a few years ago, marines appeared, submachine guns in hand, to help change its mind. A new Kola nuclear power station is planned.

There is no adequate technical provision to deal with this stuff. The main hope is the Russian reprocessing plant at Mayak, near Chelyabinsk, with western-funded medium-term storage under construction there. However, shortage of special rolling stock restricts the capacity to move material from Kola by rail. A long-term repository is being discussed. The Russians want to put it on the island of Novaya Zemlya - but it is hard to reach and its geology is fractured by previous nuclear tests. Western experts favour a site on Kola, near the stuff. No early agreement is expected.

This situation is a product of the myopia that has been a characteristic of nuclear industries, west and east. They think in straight lines, and then only about the bits that they like, rather than of full-life cycles. Only now, with the armada of dead vessels swelling, is the Rubin Design Bureau, whose gifted engineers helped to build the Soviet submarine fleet (including, very recently, the Oscar design of the Kursk), being asked to un-design them.

Accommodation for spent fuel has been much reduced by accidents. Two storage ponds at the Andreyeva Bay naval facility had to be abandoned in 1982 because poor construction had led to leakage through cracked concrete and failed welds. The storage pool and dry dock at Gremikha failed too, for similar reasons. The Norwegian Bellona Foundation has evidence that drunkenness in the workforce prevented repair. Spent fuel is stored in Northern Fleet service tenders. Four (in Murmansk and Severodvinsk), are over 25 years old and full. With nowhere better to put the stuff, all these old, badly maintained barges are accidents waiting to happen. Spent fuel stands, inadequately shielded, on the quayside.

Like the brooms activated by the sorcerer's apprentice, the block decommissioning of the Soviet fleet is producing increasing volumes of fresh spent fuel. The Russian government plans to decommission 150 submarines by 2007. The present least-bad option is to leave the fuel in reactors on board. But left too long, fuel channels may distort. Defuelling then becomes impossible, so the entire reactors have to be disposed of. Unmaintained, the submarine hulls corrode. Some have sunk at their moorings.

The west wants to help. But at a recent meeting the cost of disposal quoted by the Russians was twice the equivalent western figure. The Russians would like to be paid to clean up; the west is reluctant to hand over cash. People recall the European Union auditors' report on money for safety at nuclear power-stations, which disappeared.

The whole issue is darkened by a cloud from another source - the inveterate culture of secrecy that hangs over Russian military, especially nuclear, matters. Of principal concern today is the case of a former Russian navy captain, Alexander Nikitin. The authorities decided to make an example of him. Put on trial for high treason for revealing information about the Russian navy (information that was actually already known to western researchers from other sources), he was hounded through the courts for years until he was acquitted by the St Petersburg city court last December.

The acquittal was confirmed by the supreme court in April, amid general rejoicing by environmentalists and supporters of free speech. But Victor Cherkesov, a friend of President Vladimir Putin, who was the Petersburg prosecutor and is now governor of north-west Russia, has not given up. The prosecutor's office has appealed against the acquittal and a supreme court hearing is due next month.

Even if his acquittal stands, Nikitin's case will have had dire consequences because of the nature of his defence case. The courts found that at the time of the offence, no law existed which Nikitin had broken: by definition he was innocent. Now there is a law. It works like this, in five Kafkaesque steps: one, there are secret matters not to be revealed; two, they are listed; three, the list itself is secret; four, ignorance is no defence; five, there is no "public interest" defence. As a dissident in the new Russia told me, in future no prudent Russian will dare to speak publicly about any environmental issue except those that are wholly innocuous: perhaps the welfare of sea-birds.

The British government has offered £5m toward the Kola clean up. But any external aid must be targeted primarily at building a comprehensive partnership in which western and Russian engineers and equipment work together. Compromise is unacceptable because the safe management of radioactivity is an activity unlike any other. That a British rescue team was requested, late in the day, to assist with the Kursk, is one glimmering point of optimism that may be seen as the swirling, murky waters close over the disaster.

Britain's role in Nato's war with Yugoslavia sparked more controversy in this country than any other foreign crisis for half a century. Not since Anthony Eden's attack on Egypt in 1956 have passions been so aroused. Leading figures from across the political spectrum took different sides on the issue. The major parties were split. The Guardian shared in the debate and supported the Government's decision to intervene.

This puts a duty upon us to take especially seriously any criticisms of the campaign, including Nato's conduct, targeting, and efficiency, as well as its governments' negotiating strategy. The effects of the campaign in Serbia and Kosovo as well as the United Nations' performance in the aftermath of the war also deserve close scrutiny, and have had it, in our columns.

During the war we criticised the style of Nato's bombing from high altitude as cowardly. We did not agree with the targeting of bridges, power stations and other infrastructure. Before the bombing started we called for intervention under the political mandate of the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe rather than Nato so as to gain Russian support. We advocated intervention by ground troops and continued to press for it as the bombing dragged on.

This week has brought new revelations. One showed that Britain's bombing was far less accurate than claimed at the time. This followed earlier disclosures that American planes and missiles hit fewer tanks and artillery than the Pentagon said. Today we report that the number of Albanian civilians proved to have been killed by Serb forces was substantially less than western governments said. In the case of the bombing, the charge against Nato is that it lied and covered up. With the exaggerated massacre claims, the charge is more one of misjudgment and manipulation. No one in government could be sure what was happening inside Kosovo when the air strikes were under way.

But instead of advocating caution towards atrocity accounts from traumatised refugees, Nato governments tended to repeat them, to maintain support for the bombing. Excessive optimism about the success of the bombing was matched by excessive pessimism about the horror in Kosovo. The TV pictures of mass deportations were enough to condemn the behaviour of the Serb authorities without governments having to suggest there were Bosnian-style massacres and rape camps. Fears of "another Bosnia" were understandable, but that did not diminish the need to check that they were true.

Yet the sum of all these criticisms does not change the central issue. Was intervention needed? Some of the war's critics talk as though it began with the first Nato bomb. It had been under way for a year, after Serb forces in March 1998 started a rolling series of indiscriminate offensives against Kosovo Albanian civilians and their villages. The United Nations Security Council more than once called on Belgrade to desist.

When President Slobodan Milosevic continued his military repression even after agreeing to accept international observers, action had to be taken. His is not the only government which has defied the UN, but the world's failure to act against other governments does not mean action was wrong or illegitimate in Kosovo. The use of force did not have unanimous Security Council backing, which adds to the contradictions. But massive crimes were being perpetrated in Kosovo. That was why we advocated outside intervention and for all the mistakes and in spite of the lies we continue to believe it was right.

In his long career as a conman Paul Bint has pretended to be many things. He has persuaded his unsuspecting victims that he was a doctor, a lawyer, an earl, a millionaire, and a dancer with the Royal Festival ballet.

The reality was somewhat less enchanting: a homeless former hairdresser with the gift of the gab.

His favourite trick was to sneak into hospitals wearing a white coat and stethoscope purporting to be a doctor. He was also fond of masquerading as an aristocrat in order to steal sports cars while out on test drives.

But yesterday Bint's latest fiction earned him a two-year prison sentence after he was convicted at Newcastle crown court of pretending to be a barrister and conning Virgin trains out of free accommodation at the Caledonian hotel in Edinburgh.

On a train between Birmingham and Glasgow this year he said he was a barrister in the Lockerbie trial called Lachlan Campbell-Breedem QC and that his laptop computer containing vital information had been stolen. The train was halted and delayed while an extensive search was carried out by staff.

Because of the delay, he persuaded Virgin trains to put him up at the hotel in Edinburgh for three nights at a cost of £545. To make the story more convincing, he wore a barrister's robes and a wig that he had stolen from Birmingham crown court.

Bint disappeared from the hotel then turned up in Berwick-upon-Tweed, Northumberland, wearing a white coat. He persuaded a taxi driver to take him to a hospital in Newcastle upon Tyne, saying he was a doctor there who was urgently needed for a transplant operation.

A judge once told him: "You are not mentally ill. You have an unfortunate talent which you have used over and over again to persuade others your fantasy world exists."

He was first caught in 1983 when he posed as a doctor, but only after he had arranged x-rays, tended to a man with a collapsed lung and put 12 stitches in another person's head wound. He also tried to trick his way into a heart bypass operation.

In the same year he gatecrashed a party given by Viscount Linley, where he tried to introduce himself to Koo Stark by sending a bottle of Dom Perignon champagne to her table.

Bint has spent a total of 10 years in prison and mental institutions. In July 1993 he was ordered to be detained indefinitely at a psychiatric hospital in York after he pretended to be a doctor at St James's hospital in Leeds.

He was released from hospital the following year and was soon caught at the Royal Preston hospital and Blackburn Royal infirmary pretending to be a locum called Dr Pearce Hanson.

He groped a woman patient and told her: "Trust me, I'm a doctor."

He told the parents of a girl aged 17 who had been injured in a road accident that she would survive. She died six hours later.

He has also been jailed for tricking a car salesman out of a £83,000 Ferrari which he took for a test drive while calling himself the Earl of Arundel.

A Porsche and a Rolls-Royce were spirited away by Bint when he pretended to be an aristocrat.

Last year he changed tack and decided to go "into law". But once again he has found himself on the wrong side of it.

Every offender in Britain is to be given a computer-generated score that will tell the courts before they are sentenced how likely they are to re-offend and what danger they pose to the public, under a controversial plan to be introduced next year.

The chief inspector of probation, Sir Graham Smith, said yesterday he understood that the introduction of Oasys - the offender assessment system - would not be universally welcomed, particularly by defence lawyers. But, he said, it would mean for the first time that the courts and probation and prison services had a consistent way of judging the likelihood that a convicted offender would strike again.

Last night the Law Society and probation officers voiced "deep concern" that it would lead to sentences based not on what a criminal had done, but on who he was or what he was likely to do. The punishment would no longer fit the crime, but the criminal. It would also decide whether a defendant should be freed on bail.

The system, developed by the Home Office, gives an offender a computerised score based on factors like unemployment, literacy, family circumstances, lifestyle, history, who they mixed with and their educational background, as well as on the criminal's attitude to his or her offence. A computer would analyse the results and produce a score to enable an experienced probation officer to predict how likely the person was to re-offend.

It is not expected the reports would contain a raw figure suggesting, for instance, that a particular burglar had a 90% likelihood of committing the crime again. Rather, the courts would be told whether there was a high, medium or low risk that particular criminals would re-offend, and how dangerous their crimes were likely to be.

Sir Graham Smith said that Oasys would not replace the judgment and gut instincts of probation officers, but would allow their reports, on which the courts based their sentencing, to be less subjective. "We have to be more consistent. We have relied too much on nous, instinct and feel," he said. "It will ensure the offender gets the right sentence and onto the right 'what works' programme to tackle his offending behaviour."

More than 600,000 probation reports are written each year and used not only to decide the sentence, but also the courses criminals should be required to take and when to release them on parole or on home detention curfew.

Pilot schemes are under way and the scheme is expected to be introduced nationally next year. "There are going to be people who say they don't like it. There are going to be human rights issues, but we are not going to say 'this particular person will definitely commit a crime.' We are going to say that all these factors are going to have some kind of impact," said Sir Graham.

The House of Commons has agreed to pay £5.2m in compensation to a building company discriminated against during construction of a new office block for MPs.

The Anglo-American firm Harmon Facades (UK) Ltd lost out on a contract to provide bronze cladding for the £231m Portcullis House despite a bid £2m less than that of the successful bidder.

The four-year case was one of the more embarrassing episodes involving the complex opposite Big Ben, which has come under fire for its cost.

Last October the high court ruled that the Commons had breached European and UK law by awarding the £34m cladding contract to the Anglo-German company Seele-Avis. Judge Humphrey Lloyd also ruled that the Commons had committed "misfeasance in public office" when an official later falsified the reasons for the contract not being awarded to Harmon.

The Commons had claimed that Harmon should not have won the contract because it was forced into liquidation two years later. The judge ruled that winning the deal would have prevented this.

Parliament was ordered to pay Harmon £1.85m in interim damages and a final award of not less than £3.7m.

The Liberal Democrat MP Archy Kirkwood, representing the House of Commons commission, said in a statement that the payout was "very substantially less" than that claimed by Harmon.

At 7pm next Thursday the state of Georgia is likely to set another grisly record in the history of capital punishment in America when Alexander Williams, now aged 32, will become the fifth child offender to be executed in the US this year - more than in any year since six minors were put to death in 1954.

Amnesty International, which issued an "urgent action" appeal for clemency yesterday, said that Iran, Nigeria, Saudi Arabia, Pakistan and Congo were the only other countries to execute juvenile offenders in the past 10 years. But the US tops the list with 14 executions.

In 1986, at the age of 17, Williams abducted 16-year-old Aleta Carol Bunch from a shopping centre in Augusta. He was arrested eight days later. His information led to her body in a remote, wooded area outside the town. She had been robbed, raped and shot.

On Tuesday the pardons board will hear pleas for clemency, including one from Rosalynn Carter, the wife of the former US president.

In a letter to the board Williams - who has been diagnosed as a paranoid schizophrenic - admitted his guilt for the first time and said: "I am asking the people of Georgia to show compassion toward me, something that at 17 I regret was outside my own power of humanity."

The lawyers also plan to take the case to the Georgia supreme court and, possibly, the US supreme court. A lawyer familiar with the case told the Guardian that the grounds would be that under the Georgia constitution the execution of a juvenile constitutes cruel and unusual punishment; and that it would be illegal under a raft of international law which the US has ratified.

Amnesty's report on the case says that Williams failed to get proper representation. The lawyer at his trial did not bring forward evidence about his long history of physical and mental abuse by his family, particularly from his mother. In 1990 the lawyer was formally removed from representing indigent defendants because of his inadequate performance.

Attempts in the appeal court to get a new sentencing hearing on the grounds of poor legal support also failed, by two votes to one.

Amnesty urged Georgia last night to "offer an example of progressive human rights leadership" by granting clemency, but Aleta Bunch's mother, Carolyn, said of Williams's personal plea: "It doesn't change my mind - he should still get the death penalty."

A rocket was fired at the office of a French government representative in Corsica early yesterday, dealing another blow to government-sponsored efforts to bring peace to the Mediterranean island.

Police said the attack caused no injuries and only minimal damage to the building. But the incident, attributed to separatist guerrillas, is the second challenge in as many weeks to far-reaching plans by the French prime minister, Lionel Jospin, to offer Corsica an unprecedented degree of self rule in exchange for an end to a quarter-century of bloodshed.

Last week Jean-Michel Rossi, a reformed Corsican nationalist, was shot dead outside a cafe in upper Corsica along with his bodyguard. Their heavily armed killers remain at large.

The rocket attack took place as Mr Jospin, whose plan for Corsica has been criticised by the conservative opposition and members of his coalition as rewarding violence, said in a magazine article published yesterday that Corsicans must respect the rule of law if devolution is to go ahead.

But while the political wings of the main Corsican national ist parties have voiced support for the accords, their underground military groups have yet to show themselves capable of uniting to agree on the need for peace.

The plans, if passed by the French parliament, would transfer responsibility for issues such as culture, education and infrastructure to the Corsican assembly, which would also have the power to modify laws passed in Paris.

If all went well, a future French government would then revise the French constitution in 2003 or 2004, introducing proportional representation and creating a single political and administrative body for Corsica with limited law-making powers.

In his article, published in Le Nouvel Observateur, Mr Jospin admitted there was resistance in France to granting Corsicans legislative power, but argued that the mood may change if lasting peace returns and Corsicans make good use of their new powers.

"But if the Corsican state of mind does not change, if the island's elected representatives do not assume their responsibilities, if the violence continues, any revision of the constitution would be risky if not unjustified," he said.

When, in British Rail days, Jimmy Savile used to tell us that this was the age of the train, not many were convinced. The British people's love of trains did not extend to using them. Railways were in a long decline that continued well into the 90s. But since 1995, the number of passenger journeys has increased by nearly 30% and the railways are now carrying more people than at any time since the second world war.

The Conservatives would have us believe that this growth is due to privatisation. But the analysis that underpins the government's 10-year transport plan would suggest otherwise. A new forecasting model, developed by the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions, suggests that the increase in passenger numbers can be explained mainly by factors outside the industry's control: strong economic growth and rising road traffic congestion.

Privatisation made fortunes for a few but passengers have seen few benefits. The performance of Railtrack and the train operating companies has been little better, and in some cases worse, than British Rail. The main elements of the government's strategy are falling into place. It has created a new Strategic Rail Authority (SRA) with a remit to develop the network, and appointed a new rail regulator, Tom Winsor. At present the SRA exists in "shadow" form with powers inherited from Office of Passenger Rail Franchising and the British Railways Board. It will gain extra powers when the transport bill completes its passage through parliament.

Railways were the clear winners from the government's spending review and the 10-year transport plan. Over the next three years public spending on railways will increase by 125% in real terms compared to an 18% real-terms increase in spending on trunk roads and motorways. The transport plan commits a total of £60bn to the railways over the next 10 years. Nearly half the money, £26bn, will come from the public sector in operating subsidies and capital grants. The rest will be made up from a mixture of fare revenue and private finance, the latter being backed by future income from fares and an extra £3.5bn of direct revenue support from the public purse.

But should taxpayers get more for their money: a stake in the industry? In part, this question was answered in the announcement of the first two new passenger franchises, a 20-year replacement franchise for Chiltern Railways, which runs trains between London and the West Midlands, and a two-year extension to the Midland Main Line franchise. Besides new investment in trains and track and better performance, operators will be expected to enter profit-sharing agreements with the SRA.

In the next 18 months, the SRA intends to replace all the short-term franchises with fewer, longer-term franchises along similar lines: more investment, higher standards of service and profit-sharing. The franchise map will be redrawn and the total number of passenger franchises reduced from 25 to 22. Not all is plain sailing. With Chiltern and Midland Main Line, the incumbent operators put in the winning bids. The replacement for Connex South Central, also in the first tranche, has been held up by the incumbent operator's unwillingness to give up the franchise before it expires in 2003.

But the question of whether the public sector should also acquire not just a share in the profits but also a stake in the ownership of the industry and in particular in Railtrack, the monopoly owner of the infrastructure, remains. The idea of a public sector equity stake in Railtrack in return for government grant was put forward by Labour in opposition. Today, some 90% of Railtrack's income comes in the form of payments made by the passenger and freight operators for use of the infrastructure. But the SRA now holds the purse strings to £4bn of capital grants for renewals, including the upgrading of the west coast main line, and a £7bn rail modernisation fund for expansion of the network.

The SRA will publish a detailed strategy for the development of the rail network later this year. It will set out the principles of investment support and describe the forms of funding that will be made available. One possible option is that direct payments to Railtrack could be made in return for a share in the ownership of the network. The alternative, that Railtrack's shareholders make a capital gain from taxpayers' money that they have not earned, would seem perverse.

There is also the question of whether Railtrack should lose its monopoly on infrastructure projects. Sir Alistair Morton, the chairman of the SRA, is particularly concerned about Railtrack's ability to finance and manage all network enhancements. He has been encouraging Railtrack to enter into joint ventures with the train operating companies.

Research commissioned by the Institute for Public Policy Research suggests that such joint ventures could have an important, if limited, role in setting a benchmark for Railtrack's performance. Railtrack has an improving record on managing the existing network and is responsible for fewer delays and cancellations than the train operating companies. But its management of major infrastructure projects, such as the west coast main line, leaves much to be desired.

In the spending review and 10-year transport plan, John Prescott has delivered a huge win for railways. Now it is time for the industry to deliver in return.

 Tony Grayling is a transport specialist at the Institute for Public Policy Research. t.grayling@ippr.org.uk

The Kennedys have been everywhere throughout the Democratic convention so it should be no surprise that one of the biggest cheers on a long day of street protests in Los Angeles should be for Jello Biafra, the singer and writer who rose to fame with the 1980s hardcore punk band, Dead Kennedys.

Addressing the crowd in Pershing Square, surrounded by hundreds of police, Biafra told demonstrators that "corporate power is the new Vietnam".

The gathering came at the end of a day of arrests and marches and the firing of rubber bullets on a crowd outside the centre where the convention is being held.

The police declared unlawful assemblies for the second time this week to disperse protesters who had gathered on the issues of police brutality and the death penalty.

So far 192 people have been arrested, 59 for felonies and 133 for misdemeanors.

"Do you want to be part of history or do you want to watch it on television?" asked Biafra who is in dispute with former members of his group because he refused to allow Levis to use a Dead Kennedys song for a commercial.

"Above all, don't give up, don't turn into yuppies like the last generation!" He urged people to vote for the Green party candidate, Ralph Nader.

The day started with 30 people being arrested outside Rampart police station, which is at the centre of a corruption scandal involving officers dealing in and planting drugs, shooting unarmed gang members and fabricating evidence.

A larger march of around 4,000 people then rallied outside the LAPD's headquarters to protest about people killed by police.

A lorry with the names of 2,000 who had been killed throughout the US was at the centre of a march which nearly boiled over after a masked anarchist set fire to the American flag.

Egypt yesterday claimed vindication in the latest round of the politically charged investigation into the crash of EgyptAir flight 990, which plunged into the sea off Massachusetts last October, killing 217 people.

American investigators believe that the 59-year-old co-pilot, Gamil al-Batouti, deliberately pushed the aircraft into a fatal dive when the captain left the controls to go to the toilet.

But yesterday Mohammed Fahim Rayan, EgyptAir's chairman, said he was "99% sure" that a technical problem, not a suicidal pilot, had caused the Boeing 767 to crash.

Earlier this week, Boeing urged all airlines flying the wide-bodied 767 to make special checks on the bell cranks - mechanical links from the hydraulic controls that help to move the elevator flaps on the tail.

Boeing denied any connection with the crash investigation, but EgyptAir was delighted. "This is exactly what we've been talking about," said Captain Shaker Kelada, the airline's safety chief.

Bell cranks retrieved from the wreckage of flight 990 were found to have rivets sheared in opposite directions, which EgyptAir says may indicate that the elevators - controlling the up and down attitude of the plane - jammed.

"We have seen at least two similar complaints from the Boeing's 767 elevators by Air Canada and Air Mexico," Walid Murad, head of the Egyptian Pilots' Federation, said.

Egypt has always rejected the suicide theory, suggesting that investigators latched on to the theory to exonerate Boeing from any part in the disaster.

A series of leaks to the American press during the early stages of the investigation sought to portray Batouti as an Islamic fundamentalist. When that was disproved, subsequent leaks portrayed him as an unbalanced sex maniac who harassed women in hotels.

Although the American national transportation safety board (NTSB) has not yet reached a conclusion about the cause, last Friday it released the first 1,665 pages of documents relating to the crash - including the first full transcripts from the cockpit voice recorder.

Far from confirming the suicide theory, the transcript shows Batouti cooperating with the captain after his hasty return to the cockpit in an effort to save the plane.

Twenty-eight minutes into the flight, and two minutes before the crash, with Batouti in charge in the cockpit, there are sounds described as a thunk and a click. The voice recorder then captures three syllables of non-Arabic speech. Four of the 10 people involved in the transcription believe they heard words similar to "control it"; one thought it might be "hydraulic"; five say it is unintelligible.

Immediately after this, Batouti says faintly: " tawakilt ala Allah " (I rely on God) - a phrase he repeats 10 times before the recording breaks off.

The American suicide theory was based on the fact that Batouti uttered this phrase, routinely used by Egyptians facing difficult situations, before the autopilot was disengaged and the engines shut off.

There is also nothing in the transcript to support earlier American claims that the captain, Ahmed Mahmoud al-Habashi, and Batouti fought for control of the plane.

In the transcript, Batouti asks: "What's happening?" but there is no suggestion that Batouti has done something wrong or is not working to save the plane.

Leaks from the investigation earlier also suggested that Batouti switched off the engines to prevent Habashi pulling the plane out of its dive. But the Egyptian Pilots' Association says the crew were following standard procedure in order to slow the aircraft's speed. In the transcript, Habashi orders Batouti: "Shut the engines". Batouti replies: "It's shut".

In the space of 40 seconds, the plane descended from 33,000ft to 16,000ft before the voice recorder cut off.

On the basis of radar observations, US investigators say that it later climbed to 24,000 feet before finally dropping into the sea. The Egyptian Pilots' Association claims this is another error.

Ali Murad, the association's deputy secretary general, says: "If the engines were switched off during the dive, how did the plane manage to climb up to 24,000 feet again? What was seen at 24,000 feet were remains of the plane which fell more slowly than the main part."

Before the NTSB's release of documents, the American paper USA Today published leaks from an FBI investigation in which security staff at the New York hotel used by EgyptAir crews alleged that there had been complaints about Batouti exposing himself from behind a window, and that he had harassed chambermaids. None of these incidents was reported to police at the time, and there were statements from other hotel workers describing Batouti as a pleasant man who caused no trouble.

To the co-pilot's nephew, Walid Batouti, the latest leaks "all confirm the conspiracy being made against Batouti and EgyptAir".

Joseph Lieberman faced down the doubters and made a powerful pitch to independent voters in his speech to the Democratic convention in Los Angeles on Wednesday. In so doing, Al Gore's running mate indicated he could be the man to unlock the 2000 US presidential election for the Democrats.

Less than two weeks ago, Mr Lieberman was a relatively obscure, generally conservative Democratic senator, known to the public mainly as a prominent critic of Bill Clinton during the impeachment crisis, and known to the Washington press corps mainly as an honest and interesting, but marginal, figure within his party.

Yet thousands of delegates in the Staples Centre greeted the little man from Connecticut - "my Joey", as his wife, Hadassah, introduced him - as a conquering hero, as he delivered a smart, upbeat and generally well-judged acceptance speech.

He entered to the music from Chariots of Fire, greeted the audience with an improbable clenched-fist salute and started his speech with a Jewish mother-in-law joke. But in contrast to his campaign appearances last week, Mr Lieberman dwelled only lightly on religious themes or the significance of his selection to American Jews and immigrants.

It was a speech that set out to do four things: introduce the still largely unknown Mr Lieberman to a wider national audience; help promote Al Gore's generally lack-lustre public image; win the enthusiastic support of the black American electorate, a crucial Democratic base; and reach out to independent and undecided voters who need reasons to cast their ballots for the Gore-Lieberman ticket.

"Let me just speak to those of you at home who haven't made up your mind if you want to build on our prosperity," Mr Lieberman said, before highlighting bipartisanship and political reform as two key areas appealing to independents. "I respectfully say to you that Al Gore and I are the guys who are ready to do the job," the vice-presidential candidate said.

At various points in his speech, Mr Lieberman praised Republican leaders such as Ronald Reagan and John McCain. He stressed his senate reputation as an "across-the-aisle" legislator, who had worked with Republicans in the past and who was happy to do so again.

"Our opponents are decent and likeable men," he said. "I am pleased to call many in their party my friends."

In the coming election, this appeal to the centre and to independents will clearly be one of Mr Lieberman's responsibilities.

The senator's quirky and unconventional voting record has raised some questions - especially among black leaders - about whether he will win over their support.

In two warm-up speeches, Congressmen Robert Menendez, a Latino from New Jersey, and the formidable John Lewis of Georgia, a black man, fought to promote Mr Lieberman's anti-racist record.

Meanwhile, Mr Lieberman went out of his way to restate his support for affirmative action, as he had done earlier at a meeting with the congressional black caucus.

Mr Lewis reminded the convention that the young Mr Lieberman had travelled to America's deep south to help register black voters during the toughest years of the civil rights campaigns of the 1960s.

Mr Lewis called him: "My friend and my brother."

The impact that the man from Connecticut has made on the polls in just a few days has been good for the Democrats, and yesterday's speech has established him quickly as a formidable player in the political big league.

If Mr Gore loses in November, Mr Lieberman could be an early favourite for the Democratic nomination in 2004, an unlikely thought even two weeks ago.

A leisure firm is hoping to turn Blackpool from a kiss-me-kwik seaside resort into the British Las Vegas.

The Lancashire resort may be more reminiscent of saucy postcards, fish and chips and trams but all this could change if Leisure Parcs, owner of the Blackpool Tower, is allowed to build six huge casino hotels at a cost of £1bn, together with a conference centre and 3,000 seat theatre.

The proposal has been submitted to the gambling review body, but would require a change of legislation. Last night the minister for tourism, Janet Anderson, described the proposal as exciting, and said that, like all Britain's resorts, Blackpool had to adapt to the indoor leisure needs of the new century.

The casino hotels, with up to 12,000 slot machines, would stretch along the seafront from the Winter Gardens, with the hope of eventually attracting 30m visitors a year.

Marc Etches, managing director of Leisure Parcs, said yesterday that the casinos could be a catalyst for economic regeneration of the area.

"In Blackpool we have a conundrum," he said. "It is very successful, with 12m visitors every year, but has the 12th lowest gross domestic product in the country and the third lowest in the north-west. It has some very difficult social and economic problems.

"To turn things around, we have to be as bold and ambitious with a concrete vision for the town. That vision means persuading the government to change gambling legislation to allow resorts like Blackpool to have casino hotels."

Mr Etches did not liken his scheme to the famed gambling resort in Nevada, but cited the experience of Atlantic City, near New York, which reversed its decline by building four casinos in the late 1970s and today had 34m visitors bringing in £4bn a year.

Leisure Parcs has owned the tower, the town's three piers and the Winter Gardens since 1998.

Senator John McCain was consulting doctors in Arizona yesterday after revealing that he has suffered a recurrence of the most dangerous form of skin cancer.

The Arizona senator's office announced that doctors had found two spots of melanoma, on his left arm and left temple. He underwent an operation in 1993 to remove an earlier melanoma from his shoulder. Since then, friends say, he has had check-ups every three months. The latest tests were taken earlier this month.

The former contender for the Republican presidential nomination has cancelled most of his immediate public engagements, though he intends to honour a commitment to appear in Ohio on Sunday on behalf of a colleague.

The treatments available will depend on the depth of the cancer and whether it has spread. Independent medical experts said yesterday that there was a chance that the latest cancer was treatable because it had been caught early.

Mr McCain's news brought tributes from friends and rivals. "John is a good man and a fighter," George W Bush said, recalling the strength of a man who spent five years in a Vietnamese prison.

"He is so courageous he will just face it," the Democratic contender, Al Gore, said.

Sir Antony Duff, who has died aged 80, was the epitome of the wise public servant on whom Whitehall's ship of state has traditionally relied. The irony is that Margaret Thatcher, in her early years as prime minister, also relied on him, an experience he did not entirely enjoy.

Twice she persuaded him to forego retirement, first when she asked him to take over the role of security and intelligence coordinator in the Cabinet Office, and subsequently when she persuaded him to clear out the Augean stables of MI5. When finally retired, he spent years working on behalf of London's homeless. Earlier, he had served as ambassador and diplomat in many countries, culminating in a crucial role organising Zimbawe's independence in 1979.

Duff's background was naval; his father was an admiral, and he was educated at the Royal Naval College, Dartmouth. He had a distinguished record as a sub-mariner in the second world war, the start of a career which, in the words of one Guardian writer - in an article prompted by one of the rare occasions when Duff's name surfaced in public - achieved the difficult trick of staying submerged during much of its long public service.

It was this trait, when he was a 24-year-old submarine commander, that earned Duff a place in naval legend, after an ingenious escape off Norway during the second world war. Disabled by German destroyers, its diving planes stuck in a nose-dive mode, his submarine, Stubborn, floundered at twice its maximum operating depth.

Duff kept the descending craft stable by shifting the crew around as human ballast. When this technique failed to dislodge the boat from the seabed, where it was under bombardment from depth charges, he diverted breathing air into the main compressor, catapulting them all to the surface and safety. His achievement was recognised by a DSO.

But his eyes had been damaged in the action and, after the war, he abandoned his hopes of a naval career to join the Foreign Office, serving in Cairo, Paris, Bonn, Kuala Lumpur, and as ambassador to Nepal in 1964. He became high commissioner in Kenya at a time when the Rhodesia crisis was poisoning relations with other African commonwealth countries. In 1975, he was brought back to London as head of the Foreign Office's Africa department.

Duff was about to retire at a crucial period in the Zimbabwean independence negotiations at Lancaster House, which at last brought agreement in 1979. His long experience and calmness persuaded Mrs Thatcher to appoint him to the post of deputy governor in Salisbury (now Harare), under Christopher Soames. While Duff was credited with doing much of the backroom work, and bringing the white Rhodesian military commander, Peter Wallis, to heel, he was also said to have backed the moderate Bishop Abel Muzorewa in the British effort to keep the principal guerrilla leader, Robert Mugabe, out of power.

Elections were finally held in March 1980, and Zimbabwean independence came the following month. Soames and Duff returned to Britain, and Duff retired from the diplomatic service after 34 years. But he was at once appointed to coordinate the activities of the security and intelligence agencies, MI5, MI6 and GCHQ, the government communications headquarters at Cheltenham.

Occasionally, an unforeseen event might provoke real debate within the joint intelligence committee (JIC), of which Duff was a member, both as coordinator and, later, as director general of MI5. Mikhail Gorbachev's rise to power in the 1980s was such a case. Duff and Sir Derek Boorman, chief of defence intelligence, took the view that the Soviet leader's proposals for internal reform and deep cuts in missile stocks seemed genuine. Sir Percy Cradock, then chairman of the JIC, disagreed. As far as he was concerned, Moscow was still aiming at communist domination of the world - and he won the argument in committee.

In 1985, the affair of Michael Bettaney, the young MI5 officer caught trying to pass secrets to the Soviet embassy in London, led to a scathing attack on MI5's top management by the security commission. Cathy Massiter resigned from MI5 to disclose how the agency had monitored trade union leaders and dissenting groups - including CND and the National Council for Civil Liberties - because it regarded them as "subversives".

At the age of 65, Duff accepted the unenviable task of trying to shake MI5 up, replacing Sir John Jones, the first director general to have spent his career in the agency's F branch, responsible for domestic subversion. He steered the organisation towards combating more relevant targets, including Northern Irish terrorism.

He began to open up MI5 to discreet contacts with the media, and persuaded Mrs Thatcher to appoint an independent ombudsman to investigate complaints by secret service employees. When, in 1987, she stopped BBC Radio 4 from broadcasting My Country Right Or Wrong, a series about democractic accountability in the security and intelligence services, Duff told his staff there was nothing in the programmes to worry about.

However, his role - and his previous career as an outsider - was resented by older members of the MI5 hierarchy. The younger generation of security service officers, including many women, also believed that, while he recognised the problem, Duff failed to get rid of the unpopular, male-dominated, old guard.

Douglas Hurd, then home secretary, conceded during a Commons debate at the end of 1986 - provoked by the Peter Wright Spycatcher trial in Australia - that an internal complaints procedure, recommended by the security commission, had still not been introduced.

Mrs Thatcher's futile attempts to stop the publication of Wright's memoirs did nothing for MI5's reputation, and were probably not appreciated by Duff, who did not give evidence in the Australian courts. But the Spycatcher saga prompted another internal Whitehall inquiry, also headed by Duff, into allegations that a faction within MI5 had sought to discredit the then Labour prime minister, Harold Wilson, back in the mid-1970s. Mrs Thatcher told MPs that Duff found "no evidence of any truth" in the allegations, although at least one former senior official, who was embroiled in the whole affair, has said since that he was not even questioned.

By 1987, Duff had had enough of Whitehall intrigue and retired for the third and last time. He then turned to a most unusual activity for a former senior diplomat, and started work at a day-centre for the homeless, making and serving tea. Known simply as Tony Duff, he devoted the next five years of his life to being a member of the board of London's Homeless Network.

Duff was knighted in 1980. He married Pauline Sword in 1944. They had a son, two daughters and a stepson.

 Arthur Antony Duff, diplomat, intelligence officer and worker for the homeless, born February 25 1920; died August 13 2000

Shane Meadows juggles charming comedy with dark and dangerous deeds in another memorable small-scale and very British drama. It's distinctly different from its fine predecessor, TwentyFourSeven but has clear thematic links: hopeless fathers, striving surrogate dads, and desperate wooing scenes are already identifiable as key Meadows topics and this film, which lacks the visual poetic quality of its predecessor and is more thematically unpredictable, makes its director even more clearly his generation's heir to the downtrodden realism and defiant humour of Leigh, Loach and Blair.

Sadly he seems to be the only one in England right now: it's a heavy burden he wears lightly. The central characters here are the eponymous Romeo, a chubby black kid who manages to eat a bag of chips meant for three in a nicely-timed gag over the opening credits, "Knocks", his best friend and next-door neighbour and Morell, the eccentric misfit who wins the boys' friendship after saving them from being beaten up and desperately wants a date with Romeo's sister, Ladine.

The plot, and its sometimes shocking lurches from humour to out-of-control violence, takes place against the backdrop of poverty, frustration and desperately dull housing estate life - if you've seen his short films as well as the features, Meadows's Nottingham already seems almost as familiar as Alan Bennett's Leeds.

Its unknown cast all acquit themselves well but Paddy Considine as the complicated Morell, owner of many fantasies and the world's worst shellsuit, is particularly outstanding in a difficult part. It's unsettling in a similar way to Mike Leigh's 1981 housing-estate drama Meantime and boasts an eclectic and carefully chosen soundtrack (Beck, Fairport Convention, JJ Cale). A rare film about shifting relationships and, despite that sleeve, absolutely not pants at all.
