When you're a 5ft 11in ex-model who made her mark as a seductive assassin in GoldenEye, a rather particular Hollywood route might seem inevitable. Famke Janssen, however, has failed - or succeeded, depending on which way you look at it - to fulfil the expected role.

She has starred in a number of indie films but could hardly be described as alternative; she has added glamour to box office blockbusters but doesn't play the same character in vehicles tailored to her requirements. She's an actress, in other words, making the most of what comes along - but most actresses don't look like supermodels, and even fewer supermodels could ever be true actresses.

Her latest film brings these disparate elements together. X-Men is a special-effects-drenched blizzard of a movie that uses its premise - a group of mutant superheroes who must learn to use their special powers for good while dealing with the fear they inspire from normal humans - as an allegory for prejudice. It is smart and exciting, but based as it is on the comic book of the same name, and given the track record of comic-based films, it could have been a dangerous choice for a woman keen to establish herself as a proper actress.

"But you take into consideration that Bryan Singer is the director and you eliminate some of that risk," says Janssen of her decision to play the part of Dr Jean Grey, the mutant learning to hone her telekenic skills under the tutelage of Professor Xavier, the X-Men's shiny-pated mentor. Singer made his mark with the indie hit The Usual Suspects, which attracted Janssen to the project. "I'm a firm believer in taking risks in life, because you'll never get anywhere unless you do, and the more risk involved the greater the outcome - or the worse, but you never know so you've got to go for it.

"Comic books have been done in a very over the top, unreal manner in the past, but given my knowledge of comics - and I'm not a fan of them at all - it's actually a dark, alienated world. That's never been brought to the screen before, but that's exactly what most readers of The X-Men are interested in, because they're so often outsiders in one way or another too. And so I thought that if Bryan Singer could bring any of that tone and darkness and realism to the X-Men, that would make a great movie. And it did."

Janssen was actually born in Holland, and came from Amsterdam to work as a model in the US in her early 20s. In some respects, she's a modern version of Audrey Hepburn - another Dutch model who broke into Hollywood. She gave up modelling to study at Columbia University, and struggled to find acting jobs for four years after graduating before landing the female lead in GoldenEye, as Xenia Onatopp, the Russian assassin and nemesis to Pierce Brosnan's 007.

Since then she has wavered between bids for indie credibility (City of Industry, Woody Allen's Celebrity) and mainstream horror (Deep Rising, House On Haunted Hill); critical successes (The Faculty) and all-round embarrassments (Circus). She's now 35 and a jobbing actress: not so high-profile that she can call the shots like Hollywood's half-dozen leading ladies, but respected enough to work with some very good directors.

"With a lot of studio movies, you can't really base your decision to be involved or not on a script, because there are a lot of things that are left in flux. Working on a film for six months, you never know what scenes they're going to keep, so you have no idea on what the outcome will be."

The first consideration in Janssen's career-path decison-making is always the director. "Working with Woody Allen on Celebrity was a milestone for me because he's such a hero of mine, and I've always preferred working on character-driven projects, but I have to say, a movie like The Faculty I did because the director was Robert Rodriguez and he's a great film-maker.

"It doesn't matter what the genre is. I'd never condemn horror, for example; one of my favourite directors of all time is Stanley Kubrick, and he made The Shining. How much input the director has and who he is is the most important thing. With all the unknowns going on, you want to give yourself up to someone who knows what he's doing. I'll probably go back and forth doing different movies, and I've just worked with a first time director [on Love & Sex] because I loved the script so much, but at this point in my career working with great directors is probably the major goal."

Janssen underlines a fact that rarely gets talked about: that a decision to work on a certain movie is partly based on what that working experience is going to be like. X-Men involved six months of shooting on location in Canada, after all.

"It's always different. Woody Allen, for example, is not one to praise anybody, and he can be very critical. He can come out with something with a remark which makes you go: 'Ow. OK, I get it, I suck.' He's brutally honest at times, and at other times he doesn't speak, and he doesn't let you know what else is going on in the film. Robert Altman, on the other hand, who I worked with on The Gingerbread Man, is the director who indulges actors. He'll let them improvise and do take after take. I couldn't say which is the better experience - it's all interesting."

The trappings of fame do, of course, have to take a back seat when you're going to travel down such a winding road. Before receiving the star treatment on the X-Men, Janssen had just shot Love & Sex, a micro-budgeted romantic comedy by Valerie Breiman which gave the actress her first starring role, as a magazine writer who has to prove that she can write a good article about relationships and in order to do so trawls through her history of disastrous ones.

"It was hysterical and I loved working on it, and with Jon Favreau, who stars as the woman's long-term boyfriend. That was one of my best experiences. There were 21 days to shoot Love & Sex, and six months for the X-Men. So I was doing a movie where we shot five or six scenes a day, and because I have to play all different ages it was constant make-up changes, wardrobe changes, hair changes, with never a quiet moment and pages and pages of dialogue to do.

"Then all of a sudden I arrived in Toronto, and I was sitting around, saying, 'What are we doing? Shouldn't we be working?' I'd be called in at five in the morning, spend two hours having hair and make-up done, and then they'd say, 'Actually, we've decided to shoot another scene. We'll come back to you'. It just felt like it took forever to get anything accomplished. On Love & Sex I got in trouble if I went to the bathroom."

Janssen has chosen to live in New York over LA, emphasises that quality of life is more important than career profile, and hasn't fallen for the celebrity life - "I don't care for all that stuff, if you want to do good work it doesn't matter where you stay or what you sleep on" - but she's still a movie star as well as an actress, and has to play the part.

"It's a completely different role which you just don't realise belongs to the job. You wake up in the morning and do interviews for the whole day, then you get on a plane and you don't even know where or when you're meant to sleep. It means a lot of travelling, and a lot of talking about yourself. After a while you feel: can't we talk about something else?"

Janssen likes her role as Dr Jean Grey. "She's a very normal person. The thing that I liked is this sense of control that all the X-Men have to have. When you have these special powers you'd better be able to control them well or a lot of things can go wrong. And she's just not that good at it yet. They're all superheroes, but they have flaws."

Perfectly groomed Hollywood stars can make mistakes too, after all. Anyone who has seen Circus would have to agree that one thing Famke Janssen doesn't share with her character is a gift for ESP. "I know. Like I said, sometimes you just don't know. You can say, the next time it won't happen, but it probably will. You've got to take risks."

 X-Men is released today. Love & Sex is released September 29.

It's a truth insufficiently acknowledged that the great heroes of our youth will usually betray us before their hair turns grey, and it's been as true of the Hollywood baby-boomers as it has of any other generation. Sooner or later they all take a seat on the board and acquiesce to the defamation of all their youthful ideals, once so militantly held, now so quietly surrendered.

Directors who once waged a campaign of parricide against their cinematic forebears are now grown fat and slow, seduced by big money and bad cinema. The New Hollywood of the 1970s has become the Old Guard of today.

Scorsese, the prime mover of American cinema's last two decades, is currently trapped in a holding pattern of paralysed respectability that resembles Hitchcock's final years - Kundun was his Topaz, Bringing Out The Dead his Torn Curtain. Francis Ford Coppola hasn't made a memorable movie since Apocalypse Now. Robert Altman is in his final downhill slide. William Friedkin, Brian De Palma, Arthur Penn, Bob Rafelson, Peter Bogdanovich - all of them, and countless others from that great flowering of American cinema, have taken the money and run from anything resembling risk or controversy.

Only one director of their generation has kept the faith through the years. Since I first read his imperishable autobiography Shock Value nearly 20 years ago, John Waters has proved an infallible guide to life and movies. Since then he's never, ever let me down, and his latest movie, Cecil B Demented, is as splendidly insane as anything he's made.

Shock Value just about saved my life when I first read it in my late teens. I knew I was in safe hands when I read the first lines: "To me, bad taste is what entertainment is all about. If someone vomits watching one of my movies, it's like getting a standing ovation." Before then I didn't know anyone who could see the funny side of mass murder, sexual deviancy, 300lb transvestites, "chicken-fucking", trailer-parks and really terrible movies.

Waters helped me realise there were a lot of us out there, tired, huddled, yearning to be freaks. Since I lived about 50 miles from Baltimore in those days (when Barry Levinson's Diner was also doing the rounds), I was often able to drive to the source of all trashy knowledge, "the hairdo capital of the world".

I saw Pink Flamingos on July 4 1981, at the beautiful Charles cinema (where Steve Guttenberg and Tim Daly see The Seventh Seal in Diner: "I bin to Atlantic City 100 times and I ain't never seen Death walkin' on the beach"), and my sister and I saw some great horror double-bills in Baltimore grindhouses at the tail end of the Midnight Movie boom that video snuffed out. Night Of The Living Dead and Eraserhead? Oh to be young and shockable again!

My first copy of Shock Value was soon adorned with the signatures of Waters, his superstar grandma Edith "the Egg-Lady" Massey, the late great Divine, and Mink Stole (who, weirdly enough, now lives two blocks from me), the heart of his Dreamland repertory company. When the book was stolen in California in the mid-80s I was absolutely heartbroken.

Until a fellow Waters maniac felt my pain and gave me his copy. It's in front of me now, and I'm as touched as I always am when I read my friend's inscription on the flyleaf: "Hey Asshole! Divine isn't the filthiest person alive_ YOU ARE!" He further commends me for my "last few months of arduous 'method' filthing", though I haven't a clue what this refers to, since I've long repressed all memories of the 1980s for the sake of my mental health. Just below these kind words are new signatures from Waters and Mink, but Divine and Edie are long gone, so I'll never replace those.

Since 1988's Hairspray, Waters been embraced by the mini-studios, but never co-opted. He's never lost his thrilling ability to skewer cant and pomposity, and his worldview is now shared by millions of moviegoers who loathe the dominant cinema of saccharine reassurance and bullshit happy endings. Apart from Simpsons creator Matt Groening, no one else has managed to change so drastically the way we look at our popular culture.

Cecil B Demented (Stephen Dorff) is a lovable sociopath who redefines the meaning of those shopworn terms "outlaw film-maker" and "guerrilla cinema". He and his outcast teenage acolytes - "The Sprocket Holes" - embark on a campaign of cinematic terrorism by kidnapping bitchy movie star Honey Whitlock (Melanie Griffith gamely standing in for Divine) and forcing her to act in their schlock-epic Raving Beauty.

Soon enough Honey develops a severe dose of the Stockholm Syndrome and comes to love her captors, much as Patricia Hearst did with the Symbionese Liberation Army in the 1970s (Hearst herself plays the appalled mother of one of the gang). Demented's poster is a spoof of the old Baader Meinhof/Red Army Faction logo, with a camera replacing the machine gun, and the movie vibrates with a gleeful, vandalistic hatred for mainstream cinema.

Although he's as insane as most of Waters' characters, I can't disagree with a word the jodhpur-clad, riding crop-flexing Cecil says: "I am a prophet against profit!"; "I am Cecil B Demented, the enemy of family film! Family's just another word for censorship!"; or "Your Hollywood system stole our sex and co-opted our violence, and now there's nothing left to us!"

And lest we think Waters is some scatological buffoon, it should be noted that Cecil is the most cine-literate movie I've seen in years. Waters namechecks or quotes the New York underground of the early 60s, Hong Kong chop-socky, hardcore pornography, Otto Preminger, Fassbinder, Sirk, Herschell Gordon Lewis, Kenneth Anger, Sams Peckinpah and Fuller, and producer William Castle. And one theatre-manager utters the words: "What? Pasolini's playing - and we sold no tickets?"

But it wouldn't be John Waters without some plain old filth, like this speech by porn star Cherish (Alicia Witt): "When I was 10 my whole family fucked me under the Christmas tree. As I heard my grandpa shout 'Jingle Balls!' I cried out, 'O Santa, why hast thou forsaken me!' " Movie of the month, director of my dreams. Burn, Hollywood, burn!

When Patrice Chéreau wanted to display human nature at its most intense, self-absorbed, tormented and vindictive, he hired a couple of carriages from French railways, packed his characters in and sent them shuttling backwards and forwards between Paris and Mulhouse. Unlike Murder on the Orient Express, the assaults (emotional only) took place in real travelling conditions.

Using natural light, the camera operator was jammed into the corridor; the microphone was on Chéreau's shoulder, the continuity girl crouched behind his legs and when the camera had to do a 180 pan, everyone had to duck. "We did it because of the landscape and the movement of the train," Chéreau explained. "You cannot really fabricate the movement of a train in a studio - the actors and the camera moving at the same time. We needed to have the real energy of that journey.

"We would arrive at Mulhouse a couple of hours later, uncouple the carriages, have a meal, then link the carriages to a train going back to Paris and arrive back by 6pm. We did it for 14 days. Since we did the journey so often, we knew at exactly what minute the tunnels would come." I pondered the notion of trains so punctual you could set your tunnels by them.

Those Who Love Me Can Take the Train, the latest film by the French director best known as writer-director of the blood-soaked historical epic La Reine Margot, tells of a group of mourners who travel to Limoges (the real four-hour journey was inconveniently long for shooting) to the funeral of their mutual friend, Jean-Baptiste, a manipulative, homosexual artist.

The story is inspired by the real experience of Chéreau's film editor when she went to the funeral of the gay, manipulative, documentary film-maker, François Reichenbach seven years ago. The title is the phrase with which he summoned friends to his funeral. But woven into this is Chéreau's painful, ambivalent tribute to his father.

"My father was a very good, but not very successful, painter in Angers, where I was born," Chéreau said. "His name was also Jean-Baptiste. He was completely different, but he was also a difficult man. My father was not a such a nice person. Nobody is asked to be a nice person; it is completely uninteresting to be a nice person. But he was a good teacher as is the character in the film."

He chose Limoges for the second half of the story because the train journey had to be a long one, requiring effort. It turned out to be a suitable destination. Limoges is reputed to have the largest cemetery in Europe: 185,000 residents. The town has only 200,000 live ones. Chéreau chose the unguarded moments of bereavement to access the complex relationships of his characters (played by Pascal Greggory, Valeria Bruni Tedeschi, and Jean-Louis Trintignant). Most of the relationships are homosexual; one character is transsexual.

Was the story also based partly on Chéreau's own experiences? "You draw on your own gay experience," Chéreau said. "But I try not to make a gay film. I can say that I am interested in gay experiences in the sense that everything in gay life is not exactly heterosexual. But I am interested in the similarities, not in the differences. I am impressed by the fact that when you love someone, suddenly you have exactly the same problems as heterosexuals."

Chéreau is essentially a man of the theatre, where he has been a star since his 20s (he is now 55) although he has done dangerous bungee jumps with his career, like suddenly taking off to run the Piccolo theatre in Milan, putting on productions such as Lulu and Pandora's Box.

A year later he was appointed co-director (with Roger Planchon) of the Thétre National Populaire. Then in 1976 he did a freefall into Bayreuth, accepting an offer to put on Wagner's Ring. With the cast in tuxedos and one of the props a New York fire escape, there was a predictable scandal. But his musical director, Pierre Boulez, stood by him and he repeated the offence for two more years.

"I have been confronted by challenges all the time," he said. "At 27, I was in Italy working in a foreign language. Then there was Bayreuth. I think I have a real taste for challenges. That is the most important thing for me - to learn what I don't know already."

You could say he has something of a Napoleonic taste for conquering territories. He has the build and character for it; short, sturdy and determined (he bulldozed his recently acquired English through our interview). But when he took the risk of actually playing Napoleon, in Youssef Chahine's Adieu Bonaparte in Egypt, he, like the original, came a cropper. He admits he is "an awful actor".

"I have no pleasure in being in front of the camera," he said. This did not prevent him taking the role of General Montcalm in Michael Mann's Last of the Mohicans. But it carried a bonus. Isabella Adjani was with Daniel Day-Lewis at the time and was a frequent visitor to the set. He seized the opportunity to recruit her for La Reine Margot, his furiously energetic rendering of the malevolent intrigue which led to the St Bartholomew's Day Massacre of Huguenots in Paris in 1572.

It was a witches' brew of sex, butchery and extravagant pageantry which won him an international reputation. But to achieve the right level of malignancy, he had to spice Dumas's swashbuckling romance with the venom of his own 1972 production of Marlowe's The Massacre at Paris.

It was not until 1974 that he first tackled the cinema. A consistent criticism of his work is that it shows its theatrical orgins, but his response is defiant: "I was not born into the cinema as many French directors were, so it was a big challenge for me. But my theatre background gives me another point of view. I am happy to keep that distance".

This first film was La Chair de l'orchidée, a thriller derived from a muddled novel by James Hadley Chase, author of No Orchids for Miss Blandish. "When we signed the contract," Chéreau said, "I was shocked to discover that he was a completely fake American. He was a Swiss named René Raymond." [He was actually English-born.] "I also wondered why I had such a terrible time adapting the book. Then looking at American thrillers, I realised that his were not real books at all, just compilations of cliches from American thrillers."

Chéreau did not improve matters by making it probably the wettest film in history: most of the time the characters are standing cringing under a downpour or rolling in the mud. The imperious Edwige Feuillère of the Comédie Française refused to get out of her car; she acted from the dry back seat. "Why all the rain?" I asked. He shrugged. "I wrote: 'It was raining' all the time. I don't know why, I was very young."

A later effort, L'Homme Blessé (The Wounded Man, 1983), freely adapted from Jean Genet's The Thief but based on his own anguished adolescence, was a more substantial work. "It was about this young guy of 18 discovering the world of boys. Part of the film is about adolescence and when you are doing a film about adolescence you have to look into your own life. You remember how terribly sad and confusing this time is; you don't see any escape."

La Reine Margot, made in 1994, was a departure, if only because of the level of violence. "I hate violence in real life," he said. "But the world is in a continuous confrontation with violence. We began the script of Margot with the death of Ayatollah Khomeini in Iran and finished shooting in the middle of Yugoslavia. La Reine Margot was full of that religious violence. But I am also fascinated by the violence of sentiments; the violence of love, the difficulty of love, the violence of family relationships."

His latest bungee jump is to make a film in English. "For me that is the last challenge in my life: to film in a language I had not spoken before with English actors." He was very taken by Hanif Kureishi's Love in a Blue Time and Intimacy (which will be its title), and with Kureishi wrote a script drawn from both books. "I wanted to make the film in the place where he wrote them".

He started taking English lessons last year and from February to April he was shooting at the Elephant and Castle, Battersea and Brixton, with Mark Rylance, Timothy Spall and Marianne Faithfull. "I really like being a European director," he said. "Doing theatre in Italian, opera in German, and now English." He loves London but finds "huge differences" in the approach to working. "The English crew work very hard," he said, "but they are not interested at all in what you are doing as a director and not interested at all in French films."

"You are turning your back on Europe." he said, reproachfully.

 Those Who Love Me Can Take the Train is released today.

At last. Finally. After the terrible famine of summer blockbusters worth the name. After the entertainment drought that was Tom Cruise discharging his mission statement in Sydney, Australia - that well-known centre of international excitement. After handing over our miserable enjoyment ration coupon in return for George Clooney shouting and wearing a big jumper on the high seas. After all this, at last, a proper summer film is here. Better late than never.

X-Men is the live-action version of the bizarre mutant anti-heroes of the Stan Lee comic strip, directed by Bryan Singer, and it is preposterous and sinister and enjoyable.

X-Men are the mutants of our planet earth in the not-too-distant future, an oppressed and harassed minority which a reactionary political establishment wishes to register and marginalise out of existence. The X-Men have got this way, not through the time-honoured Marvel comics convention of the nuclear or radiation accident, the kind of fateful event that befell Peter Parker or studious Dr Bruce Banner; but on account of the general workings of "evolution".

The mutants are not subject to any debilitating physical dysfunction or unsightly disfigurement. By and large it means they are very good-looking and able to do fantastically cool stuff like channelling lightning bolts and making claws come out of their hands.

But there is a serious ideological rift within the mutants. There is a liberal wing, led by Professor Xavier (Patrick Stewart) a telepath who believes in rapprochement with ordinary humans, despite the fact that humans hate and fear them.

On his side are Storm (Halle Berry) who makes her eyes go white and harnesses lightning bolts, and Cyclops (James Marsden) who can omit optic blasts through his wraparound Ray-Bans. (Cyclops's powers are a bit rubbish, really - if he loses his Ray-Bans behind the sofa, he is stuffed.) And there is Dr Jean Grey, who has telekinetic powers. She does not have an X-Men name. Perhaps she is weighing up a provisional shortlist.

Ranged against Prof Xavier's enlightened posse are the radical wing led by Magneto - sometimes wearing a snugly-fitting helmet, sometimes not - played by the superb Ian McKellen. They are, if you will, Real X-Men or Continuity X-Men, who believe that any peace process with humans is futile. Ordinary human folk, those vanilla mammals, will only ever want to destroy mutants, so they must be annihilated, or rather themselves turned en masse into mutants by a single nuclear blast from a new weapon Magneto is developing in his magnificent lair.

On Magneto's team are Mystique (Rebecca Romijn-Stamos), who is completely blue and can transform herself into any person. And there's a couple of lower-rank supporting-class X-Men: Sabretooth (Tyler Mane) a grunting, shambling monster, and Toad (Ray Park) who is basically an ugly bloke with a long tongue.

Magneto and Professor Xavier are at war, and their immediate bone of contention is the recruitment of a couple of likely new candidates. Rogue (Anna Paquin) is a lovely, confused young woman who destroys anyone she touches. Then there is Wolverine (Hugh Jackman), someone of awesome strength, healing powers, with the ability to make great steel claws spring out of his hands. Wolverine has the most extraordinary hair of all the X-Men, teased up into two peaks at the back of the head, like horns.

When we first see Wolverine, he is earning a modest crust on the Ultimate Fighting Circuit of northern Canada. Lounging against the corner of the fighting cage, he takes on all-comers, and gives them what can only be described as a right spanking, though unsportingly neglecting to reveal his genetic advantages. It is Wolverine, handsome, macho, hairy-but-not-too-hairy, who is the star of the show, instinctively on Professor Xavier's side, though amusingly detached from his organisation, and nursing a major horn for the lovely Dr Jean Grey, lovable impetuous X-Man that he is.

Singer devises for the X-Men some entertaining action sequences, and fight scenarios, the hi-tech slapstick is shrewdly pitched short of the explicit violent level to keep the picture within its teen target range. There is a funny scene in which Magneto, bristling with contempt for homo sapiens, flips over a couple of police cars, and makes the cops' weaponry float out of their hands and start shooting at the terrified officers of the law.

But the really extraordinary sequence comes at the very beginning, a moment of sheer audacity, which if managed with any less deadpan bravado would certainly be offensive. And even as it is, it is right out there on an edge of provocation undreamt of by other mainstream Hollywood movies.

Singer devises an opening scene set in Poland, 1944, with terrified Jews being herded up behind barbed wire by Nazis; a young boy is separated from his parents and with a howl of anguish sends some Nazi goons sprawling and bends the gates open with sheer brainwaves. Which X-Man will this victim of history grow up to be in modern America? Suffice to say, the final showdown is in Ellis Island, through which he passed in 1949, and this is the location for the X-Man's toweringly sarcastic denunciation of the US as a cradle of pluralism and tolerance.

Singer's X-Men is the flip-side of happy, confident, multicultural America; this is an America at unease with itself. It is a delirious, ambiguous fantasy of empowerment which speaks for and to the angry, the enraged, the dispossessed, the geeky and the uncool. It has that aspect of darkness which Singer brought to The Usual Suspects and Apt Pupil, which also interestingly brought rumours and memories of Nazism into modern America. And it is a pleasure to see those old RSC players, Stewart and McKellen, who 20 years ago were giving us their Oberon and Macbeth at Stratford, given such mighty, meaty roles on the big screen.
